pageData.text: The ancient art of creating “magic mirrors” dates to 2900–2000 BC in China, Egypt, and the Indus Valley. The mirrors were often bronze and circular. In Japan, bronze mirrors are known as magic mirrors, or makkyo (魔鏡). An embossed design is put onto the back, with a hidden image that can be seen in the metal. The front is polished and when light is directed into the front of the mirror, the image can be seen on a wall, and it appears as though the mirror is translucent1. The secrets of the “magic mirrors” were not understood by mathematicians and physicists until 2005.

Physicists are now using the knowledge learned from magic mirrors and attempting to create 3D projections. Researchers have used liquid crystals to construct a flat magic window. The flat magic window is a transparent device that shows a hidden image when light is directed toward it. The researchers hope that the magic window can be used to create artistic magic windows or movies and allow for 3D images to be viewed at different distances and angles2.

1Moon, J. (2014). The magic mirror maker. Kyoto Journal.
https://www.kyotojournal.org/renewal/the-magic-mirror-maker/

2 Optica. (2022). Inspired by an ancient light trick, “flat magic window” technology could enable a new type of 3D display. SciTech Daily.
https://scitechdaily.com/inspired-by-an-ancient-light-trick-flat-magic-window-technology-could-enable-a-new-type-of-3d-display/

pageData.text: Thin lenses and spherically curved mirrors can produce coherent images of light-emitting objects. The relationships between the images and objects for these optical elements are given by the thin lens equation, which is written as:

pageData.desc: Equation 1: equation one over f equals 1 over d sub o plus 1 over d sub i
pageData.altText: Equation 1: one over f equals 1 over d sub o plus 1 over d sub i

pageData.text: where f is of the lens or mirror, do is the distance between the object and the mirror (or lens), and di is the distance between the image and the mirror (or lens), as shown in Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagram of an illuminated object with a lens in support and a screen behind both
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of an illuminated object with a lens in support and a screen behind both

pageData.text: By measuring do and di , the focal length can be determined.

Images are classified as <u><button class='glossary-text'>real images</button></u> or <u><button class='glossary-text'>virtual images,</button></u> but this lab will only cover real images which are found by seeing where a crisply focused image of the object appears on a screen.

Another important quantity in geometric optics is the of the lens or mirror. The magnification, M, is the ratio of image size to object size. If the image is larger than the object, M is greater than 1, and if it is smaller, M is smaller than 1. The convention in geometric optics is that if the image is inverted, M is negative and M is positive if the image is not inverted relative to the object. In this lab, you will use the Thin Lens Equation to make a careful measurement of the focal length of a lens and make qualitative observations about image magnifications.

pageData.question: Using the thin lens equation, determine the focal length of a convex lens if the object distance (do) is 50 cm, and the image distance (di) is 12.5 cm.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Plug in the values do = 50 cm and di = 12.5 cm into the thin lens equation. Solving the right side of the equation gives you: 1/f = 1/10 Solving for f gives us f = 10 cm

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning, you will make the screen. Then, you will set up the screen, lens and candle. In Activity 1, you will adjust the distance to project a real image onto the screen. Then, you will photograph the image. Next, you will move the candle and observe the changes in the image. Then, you will calculate the magnification of the image. Next, you will measure the object and the image distances. Then, you will move the lens to a new distance from the screen and repeat this for 4 trials. Then, you will calculate the reciprocals of the object and image distances. Next, you will graph 1/object distance versus 1/image distance. In the extension activity, you will move the lens set up to different focal lengths. Then, you will observe the image created and describe the relationships between the image and the object. Finally, you will draw a ray diagram for an Activity 1 trial.

Which statement best describes what the thin lens equation indicates about the image formed by a very distant object?  This is, in fact, the most often used definition of the focal length of a lens or mirror.

options.text: In the thin lens equation, a large object distance means that an image is formed at the focus.
In the thin lens equation, a small object distance means that an image is formed far from the focus.

In the thin lens equation, a small object distance means that an image is formed at the focus.
None of these describe what the thin lens equation indicates about the image formed by a very large distance object.

pageData.text: Adjust the position of the candle so that it is at an object distance, do , of about 30 cm from the lens. Light the candle and confirm that a is formed on the screen. A real image is formed when the flame is projected on the screen (Figure 3). Dim the lights in the work area as needed to better view the images projected on the screen, but not so dark that you cannot see comfortably. Record this as the object distance (do ) for Trial 1 in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Activity setup showing a lit candle directly in front of a lens which sits on an elevated lens stand on top of a few books; behind the lens is a paper screen showing the candle's reflection
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Activity setup showing a lit candle directly in front of a lens which sits on an elevated lens stand on top of a few books; behind the lens is a paper screen showing the candle's reflection

pageData.text: Take a photograph of the experiment setup with the candle lit.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Slowly and carefully move the candle closer to and farther from the lens until the image on the screen comes into focus. The image is in sharp focus when moving the candle both farther and closer to the lens makes the image noticeably fuzzier.
Observe the size and inversion of the image. Use the conventions described in the background section to numerically to record the image M, for Trial 1 in Data Table 1.

Use the measuring tape to measure the distance from the center of the candle (the location of the candle flame) to the center of the lens. Hold the measuring tape flat along the work surface parallel to the experiment setup to avoid changing the positions of the candle and lens (Figure 4).

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Activity setup showing a lit candle, lens stand, and books with a measuring tape laying parallel to the experiment setup
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Activity setup showing a lit candle, lens stand, and books with a measuring tape laying parallel to the experiment setup

pageData.text: Measure the distance from the center of the lens to the screen using the same technique as Step 5. Record this as the image distance (di ) for Trial 1 in Data Table 1.

For each of four additional trials, adjust the elevated lens so it is at a new image distance from the screen; then, repeat Steps 3–6. Two of the additional image distances should be between 10 cm and 15 cm; the other two additional image distances should be between 15 cm and 40 cm. Record the data in Data Table 1.
Calculate the reciprocals for the object distance and image distance for each trial. Record the results in Data Table 1.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets, to plot the reciprocal of the object distance (1/do ) over the reciprocal of the image distance (1/di ) for each trial in Data Table 1. Find and include the best fit line for the graph. Record the slope and y-intercept of the line.
In the Extension Activity, you will observe what happens to the image created at different lens conditions. You will then draw a ray diagram for one of the trials from Activity 1.

typeBefore.text: You might have noticed that measurements became more difficult when the object distance approached the . Use your measurement of the focal length to explore this behavior. Record your responses to the questions in this activity in the Lab Notebook.

pageData.text: What happens to the image distance when do ≈ f ? Explore this by projecting the image onto a wall from 2–4 meters away. For the purposes of this exercise, an image distance of a few meters can be considered to approach infinity.

Now explore what happens to the image distance when di ≈ f. Place the object very far from the lens and see where it produces an image. The image will be very small, so look for a well-defined dot of light. This must be done in a very dark room where the object is the only source of light (including reflections of the object). Move the lens back and forth to find the image distance at which this dot is as small and crisp as possible. Again, consider an object distance of a few meters to be effectively infinity.

text: The focus of a lens or mirror is defined as the point at which light rays from infinity (or an approximation of infinity) converge. So, this second measurement with the light at infinity produces a direct measurement of the focal length. The focal length is simply equal to the image distance with an object at infinity. Does this measurement agree with your careful measurement from the lab?

pageData.text: Based on these observations, explain what happens to the Thin Lens Equation when do ≈ ∞ and di ≈ ∞? Describe the relationships between images or objects at infinity and the focal length by completing these general statements:

text: An object placed at the focus of a lens makes an image at…
An object placed at a very large distance from the lens produces an image at…

typeBefore.title:
B
 Ray Diagram (8 steps)
typeBefore.text: Ray diagrams are used to provide some qualitative answers and intuition about the behavior of thin lenses and mirrors, however a carefully drawn diagram can give surprisingly good quantitative results. In this activity, you will draw a scale drawing of a ray diagram for one of the trials in Activity 1 and compare the graphical computation to the actual image distance.

pageData.text: Choose one of the trials from Data Table 1 to determine the appropriate scale for the diagram. Calculate the sum of the object and image distances from the selected trial to determine the entire size of the experiment.

Divide the sum by the length of the longest side of a blank sheet of paper, and then round this number up to the nearest whole number. This whole number represents how many centimeters in the actual experiment are equal to 1 cm on the sheet of paper. This is the scale that will be used to create the diagram and can be represented as a ratio (for example, 2:1).
Orient the paper lengthwise. Near the left edge of the paper, along the center line, draw a dot and label it as “Object.”
Use a straight edge, such as a ruler, to draw a line from the “Object” to the opposite edge of the paper. The line, also known as the principal axis, should run parallel to the length of the paper.

Using the predetermined scale, and the same trial data from Step 1, determine the position of the center of the lens on the diagram relative to the “Object.” Draw a dot at this position along the principal axis. Draw outward arrows at the top and bottom of this vertical axis as in Figure 5 to indicate it is the convex (converging) lens.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Axis showing the converging lens, focal point, and object
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Axis showing the converging lens, focal point, and object

pageData.text: Use a straight edge to draw a vertical line through the center of the lens perpendicular to the principal axis.
Draw the three principal rays extending from the “Object” through the lens.

text: One ray runs parallel to the principal axis and refracts through the focal point.
A second ray passes through the center of the lens, and due to the thinness of the lens, is not refracted.
A third ray passes through the focal point and refracts parallel to the principal axis.

pageData.text: Identify where the three rays converge on the diagram. Label this point as “Image.” Determine the actual image distance from the scale diagram. How does this image distance compare to the measured image distance from Activity 1? Take a picture of your diagram and upload it to the Lab Notebook.

data.title: Focal length
data.content: The distance between the center of a lens or curved mirror and its focus

data.title: Magnification (M)
data.content: The ratio of image size to object size

data.title: Real image
data.content: An image of an object formed by rays of light coming to a focus (as after passing through a lens)

data.title: Virtual image
data.content: An image (such as one seen in a plane mirror) formed of points from which divergent rays (as of light) seem to emanate without actually doing so
